pros:
Vacation days
Sick days
Holiday pay/holiday in lieu
Mental health
Health benefits
Food/Beverage benefits
Competitive pay
cons:
I started with Starbucks almost 7 years ago as a barista because I needed a job. I still remember the moment my trainer showed me the inscription of our mission statement on the inside lip of my apron, and how it was close to our hearts so we live by it. That culture is what encouraged me to develop to Store Manager, and that culture has been absent for years.

Store managers are expected to work at all hours of the day, every day. With Covid complications we are always on call and can never truly have a work life balance. Lyra can’t be used as a bandaid for a problem like this.
Store Managers are living in a threat state. What boggles my mind is they asked us to prepare and set aside time for PDC’s, and after those schedules are posted with development conversations, we are being instructed to cut labor and non coverage so they can meet goals for the quarter. With stores unionizing left and right isn’t this the EXACT time to be making space for our partners and working through issues in our stores? What about prioritizing developing our next level leaders, especially with all the open store manager positions right now? My partners have been to hell and back during Covid and they deserve to be heard. I put my heart and soul into my store and feel no support or gratitude from corporate. I fell in love with the mission of this company, and I see efforts being made, however it often does not feel genuine or perhaps two faced. I thought I’d be a lifer with Starbucks but now more than ever I’m considering hanging up my apron for good.

review_title: Very stressful environment for management and mediocre pay for baristas and Supervisors
job_title: Store Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: 401k with 5% match, Free coffee, Parental leave, SIP, Free tuition with ASU....
cons: Company does not support managers with a realistic labor for buisness and a good attendance policy. Baristas and SSV if they don't feel like working a day they will just call the store and say I have a headache, or fever, or something else and even if they are doing that weekly you can't do anything about it unless they miss more than 40% of their shifts in the last 6 to 8 weeks. If you hold a barista or SSV accountable they will call your DM or corporate and create a fake story.  If you hold any partner accountable for performance or punctuality they end up quiting and even if you leave notes or put not rehireble they end up getting hired next month in other store. Company pay only $10 for a barista and $12.70 for SSV so it is very hard to retain them because they can get much higher pay or similar with less stress. Whenever you talk to your DM to share concerns about low wages or the low amount of hours they give for labor that does not support business growth, stress partners and leaves the DM end up blaming things on you. Your DM will make you feel like you are a bad manager and that people leaves leaders and not the company.

pros: The benefits are hard to pass up! The company is known for setting up its employees with the full package and more (seriously it was hard to keep track of all its perks). The fellow baristas are also amazing. I enjoyed all the friendships and support I got while I was there.
cons: I mentioned how great the benefits are, well you’ll have to take advantage of them all because of the flexing hours and your pay. Your hours could decline with no warning so you might have to resort to picking up shifts at other stores or responding to call outs. Starbucks is getting better with their wages but they still have always to go. The biggest con has to be the stress. Specifically if you work in a drive thru location the pressure to meet times is always there, it can seem like nothing is good enough. While you’re struggling to keep the money coming in you also have to keep the customers happy. This may seem basic knowledge but mixed together I found that it can ask too much from a barista.

job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Once you're working full time Starbucks will cover 98% of your tuition for ASU online courses for your first degree
cons:
I was very disappointed with the lack of trust and support my managers, assistant managers, and district managers would give the baristas. I remember many times where either I or another barista or supervisor was belittled by a manager in front of a customer. the majority of people who come to Starbucks seem to think if they treat their baristas poorly we would give them a drink for free or something to calm them down. Customers would act like the baristas need to do their job perfectly when Starbucks won't pay a barista enough to be able to live without taking a second job. Even though there were increases to the wages a couple years ago, paying everyone a dollar more isn't enough for the kind of work covid and post-covid shifts the baristas go to. 
TLDR:
Work at Starbucks if you want to be treated like trash for a job that really doesnt care about you.

review_title: One of the best Jobs ever!
pros: Good Money, Structured Schedules, Lovely Hospitality Outlook, Fabulous Benefits
cons: Frustrated Guests, Tiring work, Not much to complain about

pros: Starbucks is very passionate about the history of coffee, and the company itself; working there entails learning a lot about what is means to produce drinks like espresso, what it is, where it came from, and how it is meant to taste. I loved that my training process involved tasting everything, learning to make everything, and enjoying this newfound passion. I also loved Starbucks’ very generous partner discount. My favorite part was probably spending time with my coworkers, who made being there something I genuinely wanted to do.
cons:
The pay is not amazing. As a barista, I started off at just above minimum wage - a little over $9 (in Texas). Working alongside coworkers who’d been there for 8+ years, I discovered that after all that time, their pay had only been raised to about $3 more than what I was being paid. 
My manager was also not very present. She made herself scarce the whole time I worked there; I hardly ever saw or spoke to her, though she was there at every opening behind the bar according to the morning shift. This made it hard for me to create a professional relationship with her, as all my requests regarding shifts were done via email… however I’m guessing this dynamic might’ve been unique to my location.

review_title: Great Benefits, Not Always Great Environment
job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Benefits include:
- 401k
- free + discounted stock
- spotify premium (but I did see one time that money was taken out of my paycheck to pay for that for some reason)
- full scholarship to Arizona State University
- constant growth with pretty much job security with how desperate they are to get people
- free pound of coffee or pack of instant coffee/tea per week
- unlimited beverages throughout shift (at the stores I work at. Some have said only 1-2 per shift)
- 7 food items per week
- partnered with lyft if you need a ride to work
- you can transfer to a store anywhere in the world pretty much so you don't have to worry about finding a new job in a new area
- there's mental health benefits such as partnering with the app Headspace and the business Lyra for some free therapy sessions

There may have added or taken away some of these benefits since I left, though these have remained consistent throughout the few years I have been with the company.
cons:
- Unnecessarily political
- understaffed most of the time
- not great pay at the moment but it'll be raised in July
- I have had many promises that fell through like getting a raise, training to be an assistant store manager, working less hours b/c of school and having another job
- I was the person that liked to help and they took advantage of that big time
- customer service jobs + fast food jobs aren't usually worth it due to high demand and little respect from others. If you're looking for a part-time or first time job it'll be good to get experience but I'd recommend a job at a grocery store or clothing store. Even though they have less benefits, most pay around the same and as a first time job you don't need all of those benefits

pros: Like I said, this company tries to be different. It has benefits better than most other companies. It holds a focus on inclusiveness and mental health. This company would be great...if it didn't exploit its workers.
cons: Let me explain quickly that your experience at Starbucks will vary depending on what volume your store is, and your store manager. The SM has a huge influence over the store, and the volume of the store does also. I have worked in only high-volume stores. 60k+ a week in sales stores, and let me tell you it is so difficult. Physically and mentally it is difficult every single day. They barely staff the stores, and we can't even really add more staff because they build the stores so small you can only fit like 8 people behind the bar comfortably. They push us to the absolute limit in terms of numbers. I am in texas and the barista's aren't even paid a living wage here. Their wage is 10.50 and a living wage in texas is about 12$ an hour. Shift supervisors make 13$ and they work theyselves silly every day trying to troubleshoot the issues that arrise at a high-volume location. One person calls in and suddenly everyone is pouring sweat trying to overcompensate the already thin labor. Its honestly ridiculous how much they exploit us and covering it up with the phrase "but our benefits are great."

review_title: Love my store, don’t love the company
pros: Flexible schedule, great co-workers and welcoming environment. My manager is super understanding and easygoing and hears us out when needed. Discount is good and benefits are excellent. I love creating and maintaining good relationships with my co-workers as well as the regulars in our store. Some aspects of the job are fun and creative like building drinks and creating art/posting events on our store chalkboard.
cons: The customers really ruin the experience for a lot of baristas, myself included. This company has a “apologize even if you did nothing wrong” mentality that doesn’t sit right with me. Things were a lot different when Howard Schulz was CEO vs. now. It’s too taxing and not worth the minimum wage when customers are as demanding as they are and constantly unsatisfied. Nothing you do will ever be good enough even if they tell you otherwise. I would only recommend this job to someone who wants to work part time while in school or someone who wants a second job as side money. Working full time at this job is grueling and developing in this company is plausible but borderline unbearable. If you are a leader (manager or supervisor) most of the time you will receive little to no support from the higher ups unless you have a gem for a District Manager. Your issues will always be met with a similar response that’s wishy-washy (something along the lines of  “upholding the mission and values means putting the customer first,” “I hear your concerns, BUT…” etc. etc.) Be wary of the false premise that you will be seen, heard and supported by the company, as this will usually only apply to your immediate store (if you get a good team including manager and shift leads).

pros: They have great benefits, such as health insurance, 401(K), and Bean stock. Starbucks gives you a certain amount of money for you to invest in stocks or to add it to your 401(K). Being employed at Starbucks give you certain perks such a free drinks and 1 free food for each shift you work. Starbucks also has a more versatile uniform option now, which allows partners to have different colored dyed hair. Also, depending on the people at your store you tend to make a lot of work friends.
cons: Some of the cons at working at Starbucks is the long hours depending what time your store closes. Some stores close as late as 11:00 p.m, while there are some twenty-four hours. Another con is that they do not tell you that if you close you will be cleaning A LOT. One of your responsibilities as a barista is to clean your store before you close, this means you have to sweep, mop, wash dishes, and clean drains. If you are an individual who does not like labor such as this, I highly do not recommend this job.

review_title: Demanding but fun depending on work environment. Underpaid for the labor.
pros: I loved working for a progressive company. The benefits were decent if not good. The pay went up a little bit every so often (once a year atleast). The environment was fun and busy on good days and chances are you'll make some friendships with coworkers.
cons: The company claims to care about baristas but managers and regional mangers cared more about themselves and their status quo. There was so much work to do and considering the pay it was not worth it. The barista role can be physically demanding and I know various partners (including myself) who sustained or furthered injuries due to job duties. Starbucks is great when your partners are good people but if you have toxic coworkers or managers it is absolutely horrible. The competitive nature of stores can be quite toxic and at times you may find yourself valued more as a cog in someones career goal than a valued partner. I was asked several times to become a shift and said no each time because I knew it would not be worth it, even in one of the highest paying districts.

pros:
The perks are great, like tuition assistance with a quality school, free food and drinks and even help with the stock market and psychological counseling and health benefits. 

The relationship building opportunities are great, too- both with partners and 'regulars'.
cons:
IMO as a rehire with a 15 year gap, Mobile ordering has ruined the importance of atmosphere, and if you're the noob then there's not really anywhere to Go Elsewhere if you have friction with another partner, like other establishments in other industries have- I'm thinking like department stores. In Starbucks, unless you're taking out the trash recycling and compost you're never less than maybe 100 feet away from anyone else on staff.

Also, especially in a busy store, be prepared to take a nap after morning shift before having your 'second day'!

review_title: Horrible job, inept training and policy
pros:
If you could find one without a drive thru, the work itself would be tolerable.

Free drinks and lunch break meal are good.

Nobody gives a damn, which could be nice if that's the kind of environment you like.
cons:
I did not anticipate the headsets causing me to have panic attacks, or the way a drive thru changes the entire character of the work. Being nice to customers is great, especially after a year of pandemic isolation, but the drive thru is just like being a human vending machine, and everything in the store revolves around that drive thru.

Nearly everyone behind the counter wears a headset, and they have conversations over them, so you're left standing there like, "What the hell is everyone talking about? Am I even here?"

Everything behind the counter was a constant mess and nobody, including the GM, seemed to give a damn about it. If you've ever worked as a cook or bartender at a professional establishment (not a chain), you'd gasp when you see it. I'm not talking health code violations so much as incompetence and laziness.

Training follows the fast food model of watching bad videos on a computer, and then a shift manager (one of several who apparently work every shift together--I don't know if I even met a non-manager who wasn't a new hire) rush like mad through a checklist of tasks. The really shocking thing is they have no printed material anywhere and forbid producing such materials. "Corporate secrets." It's incompetent instruction by design. Literally everyone I've ever met who works at Starbucks says it took them six months to learn all the recipes--and it's not that hard of a recipe book, just horribly, horribly, taught. With proper instruction, it would take two weeks to get fully up to speed on making drinks during a rush. Instead, they leave new hires to die in the weeds and assign them to mop/dish until they either can handle a rush or quit.

Health insurance--the whole reason I applied for the job--takes five months to kick in.

review_title: Good potential, but horrible management and exploitative policies
pros: Base pay is good. No tips, but it's livable, especially when business is slow or non-existent due to COVID. Short-term disability is free. Healthcare is excellent in theory...
cons: Using their health insurance is sometimes a full-time job. Management demands full-time availability, but refuses to guarantee hours. Supervisors are seemingly picked at random. Confirmed COVID cases were kept quiet. Employees were castigated for politely asking customers to keep their masks on. Schedule preference was ignored. Management is outwardly callous. Nepotism and favoritism are rampant. Think Starbucks is progressive? Prepare for outright racism and misogyny. They don't even try to hide it.

review_title: Not the worst, not the best
pros: None of the individual tasks (making coffees, running front, cleaning, etc) are very difficult. You’re likely to get the time off you need if you request it, and hours are usually flexible. I’ve worked at two Starbucks’s now, a drive through/cafe and just a cafe, and despite the faster paced environment I prefer the drive through by a lot. I’d say your experience at Starbucks will vary based mostly on who you’re working with. The job can be stressful, so working with people who are supportive is what makes or breaks the job.
cons:
“Karen freak outs” are definitely not designated to compilations, if you work they’re for any length of time you’ll probably deal with a lot of upset customers. I find it’s mostly if you work between 12:00pm-5:00pm, I think it has something to do with parents getting their kids out of school that adds an additional layer of stress on them, but often customers are annoying at the least verbally abusive at worst.
As stated above, your experience working at Starbucks will be mostly based on who you work with. Personally, I can take a customer being upset with me because chances are it’ll just make a funny story later on, however an upset coworker or a manager that won’t listen to you will break the job.

cons: HQ doesn't really listen to the needs of workers, and demands can be a bit too much. Efficiency over quality is also encouraged, which takes away from the whole coffee experience, and can be very stressful for people who do not like a quick work environment. Overall, working at Starbucks can feel more like working at a fast-food restaurant than a world-class cafe like Starbucks advertises.

The environment is definitely more accepting than some places, so it’s great for LGBT+ people. It’s fast paced and you stay busy, which can be a pro or con depending. It’s pretty easy to transfer locations if you move, since they are everywhere. The constant smell of coffee.
cons: Like I said, it stays busy. Sometimes you have people lined up out the door, mobile orders, and deliveries backed up all at the same time. Hourly wages could be better for such a massive company. Not every customer is in entitled, but you do have to deal with those on the regular. You’ll be working holidays. I don’t know if it’s every location, but I would need to ask off over three weeks in advance. That is a con only because it’s incredibly frustrating to have to plan that far ahead when management tends to only have the schedule done for a week and a half.

review_title: Too much stress for not enough pay
job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: Decent benefits for part time, people are open minded and it's usually very easy to get barista shifts covered/pick up extra hours
cons:
-Corporate likes to make rules about store operations with seemingly very very little insight, if any, into what it's like during peak or even during slow times.
-If you're a barista and you're good at your job, they will pressure you to become a shift. It's not worth it.
-Management structure somehow passes the buck all the way down to these shift leads. It stops with them. I worked in multiple stores in 4 regions in 3 states. This is not a unique issue. It's company wide. The stress and pressure is always felt more at the bottom. Half of your baristas won't care, this is just a school/summer job, no responsibility. They'll just walk off the floor because they know grocery stores start at 13/hr. But for a shift, the stakes are obviously much higher. They do feel that pressure coming down from ASM and SM (not to say they don't feel stress; I'm just saying the weight of Starbucks Coffee Company is carried on the backs of two groups: 1) underpaid shift leads and 2) underpaid farmers.)
